comments.body: Could this cause a problem in a nested loop (ie, deleting the outer loop var)? I'm assuming each task has its own deepcopy of variables, but not sure from context.
yep, it's a copy.  That allows us push things into variables['item'] later on to do the real templating of the name field as well.

comments.body: Would this ever return false under normal circumstances? Seems like we'd lose items if it did...

It can return false but I should be restoring the value of name here: https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/14168/files#diff-76ffc0551f8cf3d6255500316568e60bR296  and returning hte items we were passed in unchanged here: https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/14168/files#diff-76ffc0551f8cf3d6255500316568e60bL294

The _task.evaluate_conditional() call is so that users can filter some of the items in their playbook.  We're not sure if it's really a valuable feature but theoretically one cold do something like:

```
- yum: name="{{item}}"
  with_items: ["yum", "dnf"]
  when: "'yum' in item and distribution_family == 'RedHat'"
```

to take advantage of this.

comments.body: Eek, having this list hardcoded in the task_executor feels wrong... I'm trying to think of a sane way to do it that wouldn't require actually loading all the action plugins to have them register an intent like this (and that also wouldn't open up the potential for "catchall" action plugins that could hijack things).

Given where we are in the dev cycle, this gets us through 2.3 and then we need to commit to finding a better long term solution.  The drawback to not doing this is that every single network module will need a local action in 2.3

First, this is not the cannonical info for the user info anymore, you should use the connection plugin itself (which now includes vars specific to the plugin and not present in MAGIC_VARIABLE_MAPPING. 

Second, this should not be restricted to remote_user but 'all connection information' as port, host, etc can change per iteration see the `_set_plugin_options` and `_set_conneciton_options` functions for details.

comments.body: It looks like this should be omitted, since `ansible-connection` in 2.9 doesn't use a second argument.
yes, you are correct. This is to support ansible.netcommon collection for ansible 2.9. Something we the content team would like to get support for.

I discussed this with @Qalthos. While it isn't used by `ansible-connection` from Ansible 2.9, it is possible to use an alternative version which supports it. Including it here shouldn't cause any issues.
